00021 #ifndef KERNEL_SMOOTH_H
00022 #define KERNEL_SMOOTH_H
00023 
00024 /** A template function for kernel smoothing.  At the time this was written,
00025  *  the primary data types of interest were vector<T> and valarray<T>.
00026  *  Since valarray does not provide iterators, traversing the data from
00027  *  begin() to end() was not possible.  However both supply a size() method
00028  *  and operator[](unsigned int).
00029  *
00030  *  Neither the kernel nor kernel weights need to be symmetrical.
00031  *
00032  *  typename D data, are the array of data expected to be of type double
00033  *  or float.  These data are overwritten by their smoothed values.  The
00034  *  container of the data array must provide a method size() to determine
00035  *  the number of elements of the array and operator[](unsigned int) to
00036  *  dereference indices into the container.
00037  *
00038  *  typename T, is the kernel for smoothing.  The kernel is instantiated
00039  *  and configured before the algorithm is called.  It operates by returning
00040  *  smoothed value to replace the array value between lead and lag.  The
00041  *  The intended application in mind has the smoothed value as a weighted
00042  *  value of array elements in the span of the kernel.  However, other
00043  *  transformations are possible but better implemented using <algorithm>
00044  *  from the standard template library.  This implementation takes care
00045  *  of end points in a way that STL was not designed to do.
00046  *
00047  *  The kernel requires 3 methods in its interface.
00048  *  unsigned int lead() returns how many data points are considered in its lead.
00049  *  unsigned int lag() returns how many data points are in its lag.
00050  *  double step(double) accepts a new value.
00051  *
00052  *  To understand how the kernel and the algorithm operate together it is
00053  *  best to consider it in the middle of the data, then the ends can be
00054  *  treated as special cases.
00055  *
00056  *  In figure 1, a kernel with a symmetric span of 7 data points is show
00057  *  sitting over an array of data.  The center of the kernel is sitting
00058  *  over the ^.  The algorithm has just replaced the array value at ^ with
00059  *  the weighted average given by the kernel.  The next value to feed the
00060  *  kernel is the one over ~.  When the kernel receives the value over ~
00061  *  using its method step(double) the algorithm will be able to replace
00062  *  the value to the right of ^ with the kernel smoothed value.  This is
00063  *  how the kernel is expected to be able to step through the data.  The
00064  *  algorithm expects the implementation of the kernel to hold a private
00065  *  copy of data that it is sitting over in order to avoid averaging over
00066  *  already smoothed values.
00067  *
00068  *                 _______
00069  *  fig 1:    xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
00070  *                    ^   ~
00071  *
00072  *  Now the end points need to be considered as special cases.  This
00073  *  implementation of the algorithm assumes that augmenting each end of
00074  *  the data with average values near the ends will suffice.  This
00075  *  assumption may not satisfy all situations in which case a new method
00076  *  should be written.  Almost all the code here deals with the ends.
00077  *
00078  *  One can, with no loss in accuracy of calculations, imagine that the
00079  *  starts well to the left of the data and keeps moving to the right using
00080  *  step(double).  The picture in figure 2 shows this.  The imaginary data
00081  *  values way off to the left are indicated by ........ and once the
00082  *  kernel gets close enough to the beginning of the real data, imputed
00083  *  values need to be provided to smooth the transition between imaginary
00084  *  data that matters.  The ooo are data values that will to be imputed
00085  *  and they matter because the kernel will use them to compute the first
00086  *  smoothed value.  The left-most imputed o in figure 2 will affect the
00087  *  first smoothed data value.
00088  *
00089  *                _______
00090  *  fig 2:    ...........oooxxxxxxxxx
00091  *                   ^   ~
00092  *
00093  *
00094  *  In figure 3, the kernel has marched so that its center is just to the
00095  *  left of where the first observation is.  When the kernel is fed the
00096  *  observation over the ~ using the method step(double), it will return
00097  *  the smoothed value computed to replace the first observation.
00098  *                      _______
00099  *  fig 3:        .......oooxxxxxxxxx
00100  *                         ^   ~
00101  *
00102  *
00103  *  In figure 4, the kernel object has been moved by feeding it the
00104  *  observation over the ~ in figure 3.  It has replaced the value
00105  *  over the ^ and is ready to repeat the process one step at a time.
00106  *  It is the burden of the implementer of the kernel object to manage
00107  *  the data being fed to it and return a smooth value for over the ^.
00108  *  The data can be thought of as being fed to the kernel object from
00109  *  the leading end as it steps.  The middle is easy to code.
00110  *                   _______
00111  *  fig 4:    .......oooxxxxxxxxx
00112  *                      ^   ~
00113  *
00114  *
00115  *  In figure 5, the leading edge of the kernel object has run up to the
00116  *  end of the array of data.  In order for the kernel to step all the way
00117  *  to the end so that the ^ is under the last element of the array,
00118  *  imputed data must be fed to the kernel.  Once again the imputed data
00119  *  are indicated by ooo and imaginary data that does not matter by .....
00120  *                        _______
00121  *  fig 5:         xxxxxxxxxxxxxxooo...............
00122  *                           ^   ~
00123  *
00124  *
00125  *  In figure 6, the leading edge of the kernel object has reached the
00126  *  end of the imputed data and the center is over the last element
00127  *  of the data.  The algorithm is finished at this point.
00128  *                           _______
00129  *  fig 6:         xxxxxxxxxxxxxxooo
00130  *                              ^   ~
00131  *
00132  *
00133  *  Finally in figure 7, the Macarena.
00134  *
00135  *  fig 7:
00136  *
00137  *           o      o     o    o     o    <o     <o>    o>    o
00138  *          .|.    \|.   \|/   //    X     \      |    <|    <|>
00139  *           /\     >\   /<    >\   /<     >\    /<     >\   /<
00140  *
00141  *
00142  */
00143 
00144 
00145 template<typename D,typename T>
00146 void kernel_smooth(D & data, T & kernel)
00147     {
00148     // If there is no data return
00149     if (!data.size()) return;
00150 
00151     // This does not assume that the kernel span or weights are symmetrical.
00152     // See the long winded ascii art description above for details of what
00153     // the kernel and the algorithm are responsible for.
00154 
00155     // The lag of the kernel will hang off the left hand side of the array.
00156     // Assign to the lag an average of the span of the kernel at the left
00157     // hand side.  The user may have submitted an array shorter than the lead.
00158     unsigned int right_span = kernel.lead() + 1;
00159     if (data.size() < right_span) right_span = data.size();
00160 
00161     double left_avg = 0.0;
00162     for (unsigned int i=0; i<right_span; i++) left_avg += data[i];
00163     left_avg /= right_span;
00164 
00165 
00166     // Do the same as above but at the right hand side of the array.
00167     unsigned int left_span = kernel.lag() + 1;
00168     if (data.size() < left_span) left_span = data.size();
00169 
00170     double right_avg = 0.0;
00171     for (unsigned int i=0; i<left_span; i++)
00172         right_avg += data[data.size() - 1 - i];
00173     right_avg /= left_span;
00174 
00175     // Here goes the left hand side.  Stuff the left average into the lag.
00176     for (unsigned int i=0; i<kernel.lag(); i++) kernel.step(left_avg);
00177 
00178     // Step the kernel into the data, stopping the center one short.
00179     // Make sure that the kernel lead does not extend past the data.  If it
00180     // does extend past then pad it with the imputed average on the right.
00181     for (unsigned int i=0; i<kernel.lead(); i++)
00182         {
00183         if (i < data.size()) kernel.step(data[i]);
00184         else kernel.step(right_avg);
00185         }
00186 
00187     // Here goes the middle. Pad on the right when the lead goes pas the end.
00188     int lead =  kernel.lead();
00189     int data_size = data.size();
00190     for (unsigned int i=0; i<data_size; i++)
00191         {
00192         unsigned int lead_pos = i + lead;
00193         if (lead_pos < data_size) data[i] = kernel.step(data[lead_pos]);
00194         else data[i] = kernel.step(right_avg);
00195         }
00196     }
00197 
00198 #endif
